title: Thirupukazh (The Glory of the Divine)
author: Arunagirinathar
introduction: Thirupukazh, meaning 'Praise of the Lord,' is a masterpiece of devotional poetry in Tamil, consisting of hymns dedicated to Lord Murugan (Kartikeya). Composed by the saint-poet Arunagirinathar in the 15th century, the verses are renowned for their rhythmic complexity (Chandam) and profound spiritual content, focusing on the pursuit of spiritual liberation and the glory of Murugan's six abodes (Arupadaiveedu) and other sacred Sthalas (temples). The surviving collection contains approximately 1,307 songs.

chapters.name: Tirupparankundram (Verses 1-56)
chapters.summary: This chapter is dedicated entirely to the songs composed by Arunagirinathar at the Tirupparankundram temple, glorifying Lord Murugan's victory over the Asuras and his compassionate nature as a savior.

verses.original: கைக்கேயு முடற்கைய துண்டு கனியேப்பழ் முறுக்கா முனைக்கு
verses.transliteration: Kaikeiyum uṭaṟ kaiyatuṇṭu kaṉiyeppaḻ muṟukkā muṉaikku

translations.english: O Ganesha (the one with the elephant trunk and large body), who holds a fruit in your hand! You bestow the sweet fruit of grace upon those who approach you.
O Lord (Murugan), who is the son of Shiva! The celestial beings (Devas) and enlightened ones sing good songs in your praise.
You are the Pearl (Muttā), who came down to this world as a doctor, performing extraordinary deeds.
O Lord who stands as a rarity and who possesses great glory!

verses.original: ஊனாடி நீயன்று ஓர் கோட்டு முத்துக் நல்லின
verses.transliteration: Ūṉāṭi nīyaṉṟu ōr kōṭṭu muttu nalliṉa

translations.english: You who danced in the flesh (human form), once gave the pearl (of wisdom) to the one who asked.
O Lord who possesses the bow that is difficult to attain and who wields the bow with strength!
There is no one (among the skilled) who can defeat you, the foremost mighty one, at any time.
To those who think of you daily, you gladly bestow the things they desire (spiritual realization), though it is difficult to attain.
Having taken a physical form and not letting go of the habits ingrained since the beginning, and as the eyes close (in death), will I be able to utter your sacred name, Muruga?
You, who reside with the golden goddess (Deivanai/Devasena) and wear ornaments that shine amidst the music of devotion, please grant me the boon of your grace.
O Lord who subdued the raging Sūraṉ, who surrounded the sea (with his illusionary strength), by throwing the Vel (Spear).
O Kumara, Lord of the hill shrine! Manifest as my Guru (teacher) and bestow your grace upon me.
So that Vishṇu, Brahmā, and the Devas may witness (your glory), grant me the vision of your divine feet.
O Pure One (Vimalā), who assumed the guise (of a hunter) and stood firm! Grant me the strength to conquer my illusions.
Seeking refuge (in you), the daughter of the Himalayas (Pārvatī), and the nephew of Nārāyaṇa (Viṣṇu), grant me wisdom.
My limbs are weakened, afflicted by disease; O Lord, show me the path to liberation.
Bestow upon me your beautiful, lotus-like golden feet, and grant your grace.
This body, destined to perish due to the chain of past karmas (sins), rescue it and grant enlightenment.
O Lord who plays upon the breast of the Mountain Daughter (Pārvatī), who is like the God of Love (Madana) in beauty!

verses.transliteration: Amarar ciṟaiyiṟ koṉṟai yāṇṭuṉai yaṭainta tōr

translations.english: When the Devas were imprisoned, you crushed Sūrapadman and took his essence, granting salvation.

verses.original: மதத்திற் குலத்தி லெனைத் திரியா தேற் கென்று

translations.english: O Lord, do not let me wander aimlessly in the pride of birth and lineage; grant me the grace of your lotus feet.
Bestow your sacred grace so that I may utter excellent, truthful words (of your praise).
O Wondrous One, who removes all the trappings and complexities of false appearances and worldly disguises!
The young son of the Mountain Daughter (Pārvatī), the hero who rides the peacock (Mayil Vīraṉ)!

verses.original: புலன் கெடப் புகுத வுன்றன் பொற் பாதம்
verses.transliteration: Pulaṉ keṭap pukuta vuṉṟaṉ poṟ pātam

translations.english: So that my senses may be subdued, grant me entry to your golden feet (spiritual path).
O Lord, who knows the play of illusion (Māyā), sought after by the great poets (Mākavi).
Grant me the speed (of grace) so that my tongue may ceaselessly utter 'Kumara, Kurupara' (Son of Shiva, Supreme Guru).
Having known the whole world (its transient nature), grant your grace to me.
The son of Lord Shiva, who comes as a pillar of strength (Tiṭar), I seek your refuge.
O Lord with the twelve broad shoulders, whom the celestial beings (Imaiōr) worship with reverence!
Because the God of Love (Matavēḷ) shot his flower arrows (of desire), I seek refuge in your grace.
So that poverty and the diseases that cling relentlessly may be cured, grant me your divine sight.
To those who ceaselessly chant your name always and many times, you grant liberation.
O Son of the Mountain Daughter, rider of the Peacock, possessor of the beautiful Vel (Spear)!
The Supreme Reality (Param) that stands beyond the four divisions (of the Vedas or the body).
Destroying the cycle of birth and death, and desiring to cure my disease (of ego), I seek your holy feet.
Send forth the fragrance of Kumara's grace (Aruṇ) to spread, and bless me.
So that I may speak with conviction and renounce the playful acts that lead to suffering and delusion.
I fearfully, fearfully draw near, desiring your grace (Aruḷ), O Lord.
So that I may truly open my eyes (to reality), bestow your reddish feet (Cēvaṭi) upon me.
So that all the complexities of appearances and worldly forms may be utterly destroyed (for me).

verses.original: மதத்திற் குலத்தி லெனைத் திரியா தேற் கென்று

translations.english: Do not let me wander because of pride in my lineage or caste; grant me your grace.
Bestow the divine form (Corupam) and the lotus of your feet upon me, who stands before you.
O God of Gods, Guru (Teacher)! You who destroy the pain of rebirth (ceṉma nōv), protect me.
Having seen the shadow of your lotus feet, and your peacock vehicle (Mayil Vākaṉam), I seek refuge.

verses.original: சமய விவாதங் கடந்து நின்ற சரவண பவ
verses.transliteration: Camaya vivātaṅ kaṭantu niṉṟa caravaṇa pava

translations.english: O Caravaṇa Pava (Murugan), who stands beyond all religious disputes (Camaya Vivātaṅ), grant me true knowledge.
O Lord who forever removes disease! Look upon me and grant release from suffering.
The illusory transformation (Māyā Vikāram) that has become flesh and form, rescue me from its grip.
So that poverty and the diseases that cling relentlessly may be cured, grant me your divine sight (Repetition, often used for emphasis).
O King (Kōvē) who wears the flawless golden crown, grant me the vision of your true form.
Worshipped and praised by the goddess Laksmi (the lady of the red lotus) with beautiful words, grant your grace.
The entire exposition of the Vedas shines forth everywhere, illuminating all existence.
So that the defects and transformations of the body may cease, grant your grace (Aruḷvāy).
O Nephew of Viṣṇu (Mālōṉ), who resides upon the great lotus (Māmalar), grant me release.
Seeking purity (Tuppuravu) and destroying all suffering (Tuyarelām), I reach your sacred feet.
You who bestowed your reddish feet (Cēvaṭi) and received grace (Peṟṟaṉai), bless me as well.

chapters.name: Tiruchendur
chapters.summary: Hymns 57 through 92 are dedicated to Tiruchendur (Tiruchchendur), the second of the Arupadaiveedu (Six Abodes). This is the site where Murugan is believed to have worshipped Shiva after his victory over the demon Surapadman.

chapters.name: Palani
chapters.summary: Hymns 93 through 112 are dedicated to Palani (Palani Aandavar Temple), the third of the Arupadaiveedu, signifying the state of renunciation (Virakti).

chapters.name: Swamimalai
chapters.summary: Hymns 113 through 145 are dedicated to Swamimalai, the fourth of the Arupadaiveedu, where Murugan acted as a Guru (teacher) to his father, Shiva, by explaining the meaning of the Pranava Mantra (Om).

chapters.name: Tiruttani
chapters.summary: Hymns 146 through 202 are dedicated to Tiruttani, the fifth of the Arupadaiveedu, the place where Murugan rested after the war, hence the name 'Tani' (cooling/calmness).

chapters.name: Kundruthoradal (Hill Shrines)
chapters.summary: Hymns 203 through 240 are dedicated to various other significant hill shrines (Kundram) where Lord Murugan is worshipped, emphasizing his presence atop every sacred hill.

chapters.name: Other Sacred Sites and General Hymns
chapters.summary: Hymns 241 onwards encompass songs dedicated to numerous other temples (Sthalas) across South India and general, non-site-specific devotional prayers to Lord Murugan.
